page.title: List of incidents at Disneyland Resort

revision.text:
{{use mdy dates|date=March 2017}} {{use American English|date=March 2017}}
This is a summary of '''notable incidents that have taken place at [[Disneyland Resort]]''' in [[Anaheim, California]]. While the California Department of Safety and Health (CDSH) has ruled that some guest-related incidents are Disney's fault, the majority of incidents were due to negligence on the guests' part.<ref name="Snopes">{{cite web|url=http://www.snopes.com/disney/parks/deaths.asp|title=Disneyland Deaths|author=David Mikkelson|date=31 July 2008|work=snopes}}</ref>
The term ''incidents'' refers to major accidents, injuries, deaths, and similar significant occurrences. While these incidents are required to be reported to regulatory authorities for investigation, attraction-related incidents usually fall into one of the following categories: * Caused by negligence on the part of the guest. This can be refusal to follow specific ride safety instructions, or deliberate intent to violate park rules. * The result of a guest's known, or unknown, health issues. * Negligence on the part of the park, either by ride operator or maintenance. * A generic accident (e.g. slipping and falling) that is not a direct result of an action by any party.
In 1985, ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine reported that nearly 100 lawsuits are filed against Disney each year for numerous incidents.<ref name="Time1985">{{cite news |url = http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,962597,00.html |title = No Mickey Mousing Around |publisher = Time magazine |date = 1985-03-11 |accessdate = 2006-12-18 }}</ref> {{TOC right}} <!--Do NOT add an incident without an independent third-party source. Per WP:BURDEN, the editor adding the information is responsible for providing the source to back up the change. Fan sites like themeparkreview.com and aggregator sites like rideaccidents.com are not considered reliable, although such sites often link to sources that may meet WP:RS. Personal accounts are not permitted per WP:V and WP:OR.-->
==Disney California Adventure==
===Hyperion Theater=== *On April 22, 2003, a 36-year-old stage technician fell {{convert|60|ft|m|0}} from a catwalk in the [[Hyperion Theater]], prompting an investigation by the [[California Occupational Safety and Health Administration]] (Cal/OSHA). The victim did not regain consciousness following the incident and died on May 18, 2003.<ref>{{cite news |title=Disney Technician Who Fell Dies From Head Injuries |first= |last= |newspaper=[[Orlando Sentinel]] |date=20 May 2003 |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2003-05-20/news/0305200120_1_technician-fell-head-injuries |accessdate=27 October 2010}}</ref> In October 2003, Cal/OSHA fined the Disneyland Resort $18,350 for safety violations related to the technician's death.<ref>{{cite news |title=Disney Fined in Death of Worker |first=Kimi |last=Yoshino |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=16 October 2003 |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2003/oct/16/local/me-disney16 |accessdate=27 October 2010}}</ref> *On September 25, 2011; the flying carpet prop used during "[[A Whole New World]]" in ''[[Disney's Aladdin: A Musical Spectacular]]'' malfunctioned while flying throughout the theater, causing the carpet to flip over and suspend the actors playing Aladdin and Jasmine upside-down. The performance was immediately stopped and the theater evacuated. No injuries or deaths were reported.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2011/09/magic-carpet-aladdin-disney-california-adventure.html|title=Magic carpet malfunctions at Disney’s Aladdin show in Anaheim|publisher=}}</ref>
===Incredicoaster (formerly California Screamin’)=== {{Main|Incredicoaster}} *On July 29, 2005, 25 guests were injured when one train rear-ended another and 15 guests were transported to local hospitals for treatment of minor injuries.<ref>{{cite news|author=Driscoll, Gwendolyn|url=http://www.ocregister.com/ocr/sections/news/focus_in_depth/article_616976.php|title='You could hear it coming' |publisher=The Orange County Register|date=2005-07-30|accessdate=2008-02-14| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071118192124/http://www.ocregister.com/ocr/sections/news/focus_in_depth/article_616976.php | archivedate = 18 November 2007}}</ref> An investigation determined that the faulty brake valve which caused the collision, though it was installed and tested shortly before the accident, was of a less reliable make than the valve it replaced.<ref>{{cite news | publisher = Los Angeles Times | date = 2005-10-14 | url = http://articles.latimes.com/2005/oct/14/local/me-disney14 | title = Brake Is Faulted in Park Crash | accessdate = 2013-11-11 }}</ref> *On July 22, 2011, 23 people were rescued from California Screamin' by firefighters when a person's backpack fell out of one of the trains and landed on the track, causing the orange train to stop just after the loop but before the next block brake. It re-opened two days later after the train was winched up the next hill, had its damaged wheels replaced and allowed to complete the circuit.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/breaking-news/firefighters-rescue-23-after-dropped-bag-brings-disneyland-ride-to-a-screamin-halt/story-e6frf7jx-1226100331627 | title=Firefighters rescue 23 after dropped bag brings Disneyland ride to a Screamin' halt | work=Herald Sun | date=23 July 2011 | accessdate=2013-05-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite AV media |people= |date= 2011-08-12|title= California Screamin Accident 7/22/11|trans-title= |medium= |language= |url= https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ha252t9LLxM|access-date= 2012-08-15|archive-url= |archive-date= |format= YouTube|time= |location= |publisher= |id= |isbn= |oclc= |quote= |ref= }}</ref> * On May 2, 2016, a passenger using a [[selfie stick]] caused park officials to shut down and evacuate the attraction for over an hour.<ref>{{cite news | publisher=KTLA | url=http://ktla.com/2016/05/02/roller-coaster-at-disney-california-adventure-shut-down-evacuated-over-selfie-stick/ | date=2016-05-02 | author=Kennedy Ryan | title=Roller Coaster at Disney California Adventure Shut Down, Evacuated Over Selfie Stick}}</ref> Selfie sticks have been banned at Disney parks since the same ride was shut down due to one in June 2015.<ref>{{cite news | publisher=KTLA | url=http://ktla.com/2015/06/25/disney-california-adventure-roller-coaster-stopped-after-rider-pulls-out-selfie-stick/ | date=2015-06-25 | author=Tracy Bloom | title=Disney California Adventure Roller Coaster Stopped After Rider Pulls Out Selfie Stick: Report}}</ref>
===Pixar Pal-A-Round (formerly Mickey’s Fun Wheel)=== {{Main|Pixar Pal-A-Round}} *On October 2, 2014, 45 riders got stuck on Mickey's Fun Wheel for 90 minutes before being rescued. No injuries were reported.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.myfoxla.com/story/26693325/riders-rescued-after-disney-ferris-wheel-malfunctions-at-california-adventure |title=Riders rescued after Disney ferris wheel malfunctions at California Adventure |accessdate=2014-10-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006102144/http://www.myfoxla.com/story/26693325/riders-rescued-after-disney-ferris-wheel-malfunctions-at-california-adventure |archivedate=October 6, 2014 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
===Guest altercations=== *On February 18, 2012, a 53-year-old man was allegedly [[drunk]] and proceeded to assault an employee at the entrance gate of [[The Twilight Zone Tower of Terror]] around 3:30pm.<ref>{{cite news |title=Alleged drunk, violent man taken down at Tower of Terror at Disneyland |first= |last= |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Daily News]] |date=20 February 2012 |url=http://www.dailynews.com/news/ci_20004301 |accessdate=18 March 2013}}</ref> The employee [[pepper spray|pepper-sprayed]] the man multiple times, which prompted him to continue [[fighting]] and was subdued by other guests until security arrived and detained the man. Details on what exactly started the fight remain unknown. The man was eventually removed from the park and charged with [[assault]] and [[Battery (crime)|battery]] by the [[Anaheim Police Department]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Disneyland parkgoer pepper sprayed in scuffle |first= |last= |newspaper=[[USA Today]] |date=21 February 2012 |url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/ondeadline/post/2012/02/belligerent-man-pepper-sprayed-at-disneyland/1#.UUcBaI5OT0c |accessdate=18 March 2013}}</ref> The incident was filmed via [[camera phone]] and uploaded to [[YouTube]].<ref>{{cite AV media |people= |date= 2012-02-20|title= Disneyland - Drunk Guy Beaten Up and Pepper Sprayed at Tower of Terror|trans-title= |medium= |language= |url= https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RMmQilqrprc |access-date= 18 March 2013|archive-url= |archive-date= |format= YouTube|time= |location= |publisher= |id= |isbn= |oclc= |quote= |ref= }}</ref> *In 2014, at least 40 visitors of [[Disneyland]] contracted [[measles]] at the park between December 17–20, 2014, triggering an [[outbreak]].<ref name="CDC-unvaxed">{{cite web | url=https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6406a5.htm | title=Measles Outbreak — California, December 2014–February 2015 | publisher=[[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] | accessdate=July 31, 2015}}</ref><ref name="Wired52">{{cite news | url=https://www.wired.com/2015/01/vaccinated-people-get-measles-disneyland-blame-unvaccinated/ | title=Why Did Vaccinated People Get Measles at Disneyland? Blame the Unvaccinated | work=Wired | date=26 January 2015 | accessdate=July 31, 2015}}</ref><ref name="Guardian">{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2015/jan/14/measles-outbreak-spreads-unvaccinated-woman-disneyland | title=Measles outbreak worsens in US after unvaccinated woman visits Disneyland | work=The Guardian | date=19 January 2015 | accessdate=July 31, 2015}}</ref><ref> {{cite press release |author=<!--Staff writer(s); Prepared by the California Department of Public Health, Immunization Branch.--> |title= California Measles Surveillance Update |url=http://www.cdph.ca.gov/programs/immunize/Documents/Measles_update_3_-_13_-_2015_public.pdf |location=California, USA |publisher= |agency=California Department of Public Health |date=13 March 2015 |access-date=2015-03-18}}</ref> The likely [[Index case|patient zero]] was speculated to be an international visitor to the park.<ref name="CNN"> {{cite news |url = http://edition.cnn.com/2015/01/07/health/disneyland-measles/ |title = Mickey, Minnie and measles for nine Disneyland tourists |publisher = CNN |date = 2015-01-08 |accessdate = 2015-01-25}}</ref> The outbreak led to [[California Senate Bill 277]] regarding school vaccination requirements.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/california-becomes-a-state-divided-after-the-controversial-sb-277-vaccination-bill-is-handed-to-governor-brown-10355888.html | title=California becomes a state divided after the controversial SB 277 vaccination bill is handed to Governor Brown | work=The Independent | date=June 30, 2015 | accessdate=July 6, 2015}}</ref>
==Disneyland Park==
===America Sings=== {{Main|America Sings}} *On July 8, 1974, an 18-year-old employee was crushed to death between a revolving wall and a stationary platform inside the ''America Sings'' attraction. She was in the wrong place during a ride intermission; it was unclear whether this was due to inadequate training or a misstep as the ride had been open for only two weeks by this time. The ride closed for two days, and was subsequently refitted with breakaway walls.<ref>{{cite book |title=Mouse Tales: A Behind-the-Ears Look at Disneyland |last=Koenig |first=David |year=1994 |publisher=Bonaventure Press |location=Irvine, CA |isbn=978-0964060562 |page= |pages=172–173 |ref=Koenig94}}</ref>
===Big Thunder Mountain Railroad=== {{Main|Big Thunder Mountain Railroad}} *On March 10, 1998, a 5-year-old boy was seriously injured when his foot became wedged between the passenger car's running board and the edge of the platform after the train temporarily paused before pulling into the unloading area. All of the toes on his left foot required amputation. This led to Disneyland making improvements to the ride, although the family claims the park would not acknowledge this injury as the reason.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.saffian.com/danger.htm|title=Sarah Saffian - Author - Journalist - Teacher|publisher=}}</ref> *On September 5, 2003, a 22-year-old man died after suffering severe [[blunt force trauma]] and extensive [[internal bleeding]] in a [[derailment]] of the Big Thunder Mountain Railroad roller coaster that also injured ten other riders.<ref name=kabc>{{cite web |url=http://abclocal.go.com/kabc/news/090503_NW_Disneyland_ax.html |title= Theme Park Accident, 11 Injured |date=2003-09-07 |work=[[KABC-TV]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030906154859/http://abclocal.go.com/kabc/news/090503_NW_Disneyland_ax.html |archivedate=6 September 2003}}</ref> The cause of the accident was determined to be improper maintenance.<ref>{{cite news |url = http://tampabay.injuryboard.com/wrongful-death/big-thunder-railroad-death-brings-big-admission-from-disney.php |title = Big Thunder Railroad Death Brings Big Admission From Disney |publisher = InjuryBoard.com |date = 2004-12-05 |accessdate = 2006-11-04 }}</ref> Investigation reports and discovery by the victim's attorney confirmed the fatal injuries occurred when the first passenger car collided with the underside of the locomotive. The derailment was the result of a mechanical failure which occurred due to omissions during a maintenance procedure. Fasteners on the left side upstop/guide wheel on the floating axle of the locomotive were not tightened and [[safety wire|safetied]] in accordance with specifications. As the train entered a tunnel, the axle came loose and jammed against a brake section, causing the locomotive to become airborne and hit the ceiling of the tunnel. The locomotive then fell on top of the first passenger car, crushing the victim.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aitkenlaw.com/verdicts_settlements/disneys_big_thunder_mountain.html |title=Major Settlement Reached with Disney in the Sailing Ship "Columbia" Incident |publisher= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090315051823/http://www.aitkenlaw.com/verdicts_settlements/disneys_big_thunder_mountain.html |archivedate=March 15, 2009 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Some people blamed the new cost-conscious maintenance culture brought in by [[Paul Pressler]] and consultants [[McKinsey & Company]] in 1997, which included [[Reliability-centered maintenance]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Disney Ride Upkeep Assailed|author= Mike Anton and Kimi Yoshino|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2003/nov/09/local/me-disney9/3|work=Los Angeles Times|date=November 9, 2003}}</ref>
===Columbia=== {{Main|Sailing Ship Columbia}} *On December 24, 1998, a heavy metal [[Cleat (nautical)|cleat]] fastened to the hull of the ''Sailing Ship Columbia'' tore loose, striking one employee and two park guests. One of the guests, a 33-year-old man, died of a head injury. The normal tie line, an inelastic hemp rope designed to break easily, was improperly replaced for financial reasons by an elastic nylon rope which stretched and tore the cleat from the ship's wooden hull. Disney received much criticism for this incident due to its alleged policy of restricting outside medical personnel in the park to avoid frightening visitors, as well as for the fact that the employee in charge of the ship at the time had not been trained in its operation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dir.ca.gov/dirnews/1999/IR99-02.html|title=IR #99-02|publisher=}}</ref> After this incident, Disney reinstated lead foremen on most rides and the Anaheim Police Department placed officers in the park to speed response.<ref name="Dis911"/> This accident resulted in the first guest death on a Disneyland ride that was not attributable to any negligence on the part of the guest. California's Division of Occupational Safety and Health investigated the incident and found fault with the training of the park employee who placed the docking line on the cleat. The cleat was not designed to help brake the ship and the employee should have been trained to recognize when the ship was approaching too fast. Ride procedures called for the ship's captain to reverse the ship if it overshot the dock and re-approach the dock at the correct speed. Disney was fined US$12,500 by Cal/OSHA and settled a lawsuit brought by the victim's survivors for an estimated US$25,000,000.<ref name="Aitken">{{cite web|url=http://www.aitkenlaw.com/verdicts_settlements/cleat.html |title=Husband Killed And Wife Disfigured By Disney's Sailing Ship Columbia (2000) |accessdate=2006-10-18 |author= |last= |first= |authorlink= |vauthors= |date= |year= |month= |work= |publisher=Aitken, Aitken, Cohn |pages= |language= }}</ref>
===Disneyland Railroad=== {{Main|Disneyland Railroad}} *Within a week of Disneyland's opening on July 17, 1955, a [[brakeman]] pulled the [[Railroad switch|switch]] connecting the Disneyland Railroad's main line with a siding at Main Street, U.S.A. Station too soon as the ''Retlaw 2'' freight train on the siding was passing the ''Retlaw 1'' passenger train stopped at the station on the main line.<ref name="Broggie2014pp235–237">{{Cite book |last=Broggie |first=Michael |year=2014 |title=Walt Disney's Railroad Story: The Small-Scale Fascination That Led to a Full-Scale Kingdom |edition=4th |pages=235–237 |publisher=''[[The Donning Company|The Donning Company Publishers]]'' |isbn=978-1-57864-914-3 }}</ref><ref name="DeGaetano2015pp192–193">{{cite book |last=DeGaetano |first=Steve |year=2015 |title=The Disneyland Railroad: A Complete History in Words and Pictures |edition=2nd |publisher=''Theme Park Press'' |isbn=978-1-941500-56-9 |pages=192–193 }}</ref> The [[caboose]] on the end of the freight train had not made it fully across the switch when it was pulled and as a result, the caboose's front set of wheels correctly traveled along the siding while the rear set of wheels incorrectly traveled along the main line towards the passenger train, causing the caboose to swing to the side before colliding with a concrete slab and derailing upon impact.<ref name="Broggie2014pp235–237"/><ref name="DeGaetano2015pp192–193"/> During the ensuing commotion, the erring brakeman, presumably to avoid disciplinary action, quietly left the scene of the accident, exited the park, and was not seen again.<ref name="Broggie2014pp235–237"/><ref name="DeGaetano2015pp192–193"/> No injuries were reported and by the following year, the usage of sidings at stations on the DRR's main line came to an end.<ref name="DeGaetano2015p184">{{cite book |last=DeGaetano |first=Steve |year=2015 |title=The Disneyland Railroad: A Complete History in Words and Pictures |edition=2nd |publisher=''Theme Park Press'' |isbn=978-1-941500-56-9 |page=184 }}</ref> * In February 2000, a tree in the Adventureland section fell onto the DRR's ''Holiday Red'' freight train while it was in motion, damaging the awnings and their supports on the [[Gondola (rail)|gondolas]] as well as knocking off the [[cupola]] on top of the caboose before the train came to a stop.<ref name="DeGaetano2015p160">{{cite book |last=DeGaetano |first=Steve |year=2015 |title=The Disneyland Railroad: A Complete History in Words and Pictures |edition=2nd |publisher=''Theme Park Press'' |isbn=978-1-941500-56-9 |pages=160–161 }}</ref> No injuries occurred as a result of this accident.<ref name="DeGaetano2015p160"/> * At Tomorrowland Station in early 2004, accumulated diesel fumes in the firebox of the DRR's No. 3 locomotive exploded after its fire suddenly went out.<ref name="DeGaetano2015p158">{{cite book |last=DeGaetano |first=Steve |year=2015 |title=The Disneyland Railroad: A Complete History in Words and Pictures |edition=2nd |publisher=''Theme Park Press'' |isbn=978-1-941500-56-9 |page=158 }}</ref> The explosion ejected the engineer from the locomotive's cab and inflicted serious burns on the fireman.<ref name="DeGaetano2015p158"/>
===Frontierland=== {{Main|Frontierland}} *On May 6, 2001, 27 guests and two employees suffered minor injuries when a tree in Frontierland fell over. The tree was over 40 years old, one of the park's original plantings.<ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.amarillo.com/stories/050601/usn_disneyland.shtml |title = 27 Disneyland visitors injured when tree topples |publisher = Amarillo Globe-News |date = 2001-05-06 |accessdate = 2008-08-29 }}</ref>
===Indiana Jones Adventure=== {{Main|Indiana Jones Adventure}} * On June 25, 2000, a 23-year-old woman from Spain exited the Indiana Jones ride complaining of a severe headache. She was hospitalized later that day where it was discovered that she had a brain [[hemorrhage]]. She died on September 1, 2000 of a [[cerebral aneurysm]].<ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.ocregister.com/ocregister/homepage/abox/article_1380691.php |title = Jury can hear of changes to Disney ride after death |publisher = OC Register |date = 2006-12-12 |accessdate = 2006-12-14 }}</ref> Her family's subsequent wrongful death lawsuit against Disney stated that the victim died due to "violent shaking and stresses imposed by the ride." In an interlocutory appeal (an appeal of a legal issue within the case prior to a decision on the case's merits), the [[California Supreme Court]] held that amusement parks are considered "[[common carriers]]" similar to commercially operated planes, trains, elevators and ski lifts. This ruling imposed a heightened duty of care on amusement parks and requires them to provide the same degree of care and safety as other common carriers.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/news/archive/2005/06/16/state/n163227D85.DTL |title=Amusement parks liable for safety of thrill rides, state court rules |publisher=San Francisco Chronicle |date=2005-06-16 |accessdate=2006-12-14 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060911185540/http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=%2Fnews%2Farchive%2F2005%2F06%2F16%2Fstate%2Fn163227D85.DTL |archivedate=September 11, 2006 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>''Gomez v. Superior Court (Walt Disney Co.)'', [http://online.ceb.com/calcases/C4/35C4t1125.htm 35 Cal. 4th 1125] (2005).</ref> Disney settled the lawsuit for an undisclosed sum after the interlocutory appeal but before a decision was rendered on the case's merits. The victim's medical costs were estimated at more than US$1.3 million.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://biz.yahoo.com/ap/070104/disneyland_lawsuit.html?.v=1 |title=Settlement Reached in Wrongful Death Suit Against Disney |publisher=AP |date=2007-01-05 |accessdate=2007-01-05 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070212011933/http://biz.yahoo.com/ap/070104/disneyland_lawsuit.html?.v=1 |archivedate=February 12, 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
===It's a Small World=== {{main|It's a Small World}} * On November 27, 2009, the ride broke down while a guest with [[quadriplegic|quadriplegia]] was on the ride. The guest was stuck in the ride's "Goodbye Room", the final setting of It's a Small World, for between 30 and 40 minutes before being evacuated. As he suffered from medical conditions that were aggravated by the "blaring music" and inability to exit the ride, he sued Disney for not having adequate evacuation procedures for disabled guests on that ride, and for not providing the proper warning developed for those who could not evacuate during a ride stoppage. On March 26, 2013, the jury awarded the man US$8,000.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ocregister.com/news/ride-501541-martinez-disney.html |title=$8,000 awarded to man stuck on Small World ride |publisher=Orange County Register |date=2013-03-27 |accessdate=2013-03-27 |author=Vik Jolly}}</ref> * On the night of February 28, 2015, a small fire broke out in a backstage area of the park relatively close to the attraction. The flames were reported around 9:20PM, and were said to have been caused by the fireworks show that was rescheduled earlier that evening due to rain. A park spokeswoman said that the flames were contained by around 9:48PM, and no injuries were reported. The attraction reopened on March 1, 2015.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nbclosangeles.com/news/local/Fire-Breaks-Out-at-Disneyland-Fireworks-May-Have-Started-Blaze-294547901.html |title=Fire Breaks Out at Disneyland; Fireworks May Have Sparked Small Blaze |publisher=NBC Southern California |date=2015-02-28 |accessdate=2015-03-01 |author=Willian Avila}}</ref>
===Matterhorn=== {{Main|Matterhorn Bobsleds}} *On May 15, 1964, a 15-year-old boy from Long Beach, California was injured after he stood up in the Matterhorn Bobsleds and fell out. It was reported that his restraint was undone by his ride companion. He died three days later as a result of those injuries. This was Disneyland's first fatality.<ref name="Koenig 1994 170">[[#Koenig94|Koenig 1994]]: 170</ref> *On January 3, 1984, a 48-year-old woman was killed and decapitated when she was thrown from a Matterhorn bobsled car and struck by the next oncoming bobsled. The spot where she was killed is now called "Dolly's Drop" by cast members.<ref name="Koenig 1994 174-175">[[#Koenig94|Koenig 1994]]: 174-175</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1356&dat=19840104&id=sxYVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=LAYEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5580,1816423 | date = 1984-01-04 | title = Visitor Dies on Disney Attraction. | publisher = Ocala Star-Banner | accessdate = 2010-12-02}}</ref> An investigation found that her seat belt was not buckled. It is unclear whether the victim deliberately unfastened her belt or if the seat belt malfunctioned.<ref>[https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/64485100.html?dids=64485100:64485100&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Jul+17%2C+1985&author=JEFFREY+A.+PERLMAN&pub=Los+Angeles+Times+(pre-1997+Fulltext)&edition=&startpage=1&desc=Dannemeyer%2C+Dornan+Oppose+Regulation+Safety+of+Park+Rides+Stirs+Fight+in+Congress Abstract of LA Times Archive article mentioning death in 1984] (Abstract does not contain collaborating details, but full article may)</ref>
===Monorail=== {{Main|Disneyland Monorail System}} *On a [[Grad Nite]] on June 8, 1966, a 19-year-old man from Northridge, California, was killed while attempting to sneak into the park by climbing onto the monorail track. Ignoring the shouted warnings of a security officer, he was struck by the train and dragged 30 to 40 feet down the track. The security guard in question later stated he had to "hose the kid off the underside".<ref name="Koenig 1994 170"/>
===PeopleMover=== {{Main|PeopleMover}} *In August 1967, a 16-year-old boy from Hawthorne, California was killed while jumping between two moving PeopleMover cars as the ride was passing through a tunnel. He stumbled and fell onto the track, where an oncoming train of cars crushed him beneath its wheels, dragging his body a few hundred feet before it was stopped by a ride operator. The attraction had only been open for one month at the time.<ref name="Koenig 1994 171">[[#Koenig94|Koenig 1994]]: 171</ref> *In 1972, four teenage girls were riding the PeopleMover when one teenager lost her mouse ears cap. She and her cousin jumped onto the track to retrieve them. Realizing they had to get on a different PeopleMover car, the first girl successfully got into a car, while the second girl ran through a tunnel and out the exit, and then fell into a guard rail and onto the concrete {{convert|30|ft|m|0}} below. She broke an arm, hip, and pelvis; she had to be placed in a body brace and have a pin inserted into her leg. She sued Disney for not having any warnings about the exit.<ref>[[#Koenig94|Koenig 1994]]: 174</ref> *On June 7, 1980, an 18-year-old guest was crushed and killed by the PeopleMover while jumping between moving cars. The accident occurred as the ride entered the SuperSpeed tunnel and was very similar to the 1967 incident.<ref>[[#Koenig94|Koenig 1994]]: 173-174</ref>
===Rivers of America=== {{Main|Rivers of America (Disney)}} *On June 20, 1973, an 18-year-old New York resident and his 10-year-old brother stayed on Tom Sawyer's Island past closing time by hiding in an area that is off-limits to guests. When they wanted to leave the island, they decided to swim across the river, despite the younger brother not knowing how to swim. The 18-year-old attempted to carry his younger brother on his back and drowned halfway across. His body was found the next morning. The younger brother was able to stay afloat by "dog paddling" until a ride operator rescued him.<ref name="Koenig 1994 171"/> *On June 4, 1983, an 18-year-old boy from Albuquerque, New Mexico drowned in the Rivers of America while trying to pilot a rubber emergency boat from Tom Sawyer's Island that he and a friend had stolen from a restricted area of the island during Disneyland's annual Grad Nite. Both individuals were intoxicated at the time of the incident. The victim's mother [http://www.sandiegohaunted.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/philip.png sued] Disneyland for negligence in even allowing her inebriated son onto the premise as well as the travel agency that arranged the trip for not properly supervising the teenagers. The lawsuits were unsuccessful.<ref name="Koenig 1994 174-175"/>
===Roger Rabbit's Car Toon Spin=== {{Main|Roger Rabbit's Car Toon Spin}} * On September 22, 2000, a 4-year-old boy fell out of the ride vehicle and was dragged underneath the car, causing serious internal injuries, cardiac arrest and brain damage.<ref>{{cite news |url = https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/61252422.html?dids=61252422:61252422&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Sep+28%2C+2000&author=MEG+JAMES&pub=Los+Angeles+Times&edition=&startpage=9&desc=Police+Say+Boy+Fell+From+Open+Side+of+Disney+Car |title = Police Say Boy Fell From Open Side of Disney Car |publisher = Los Angeles Times |date = 2000-09-28 |accessdate = 2006-12-06 | first=Meg | last=James }}</ref> On October 7, 2000, Disneyland changed its emergency policy and began instructing ride operators to call 911 first, instead of the Disney security center, in order to speed emergency staff to any incident on park property. Records showed that more than five minutes passed between the time the victim fell out of the ride vehicle and emergency personnel were contacted. A Disney spokesman claimed that the timing of this policy change and this incident were coincidental.<ref name="Dis911">{{cite news |url = http://www.thefreelibrary.com/DISNEYLAND+CHANGES+ITS+911+POLICY-a083403463 |title = Disneyland Changes its 911 Policy |publisher = Daily News (Danielle Herubin and Tony Saavedra) |date = 2000-10-21 |accessdate = 2007-05-04 }}</ref> An investigation ending in December 2000 concluded that a lap bar had malfunctioned and the victim was placed in the wrong seat in the ride vehicle, too close to the opening.<ref name="toonsettle"/> Three months after the incident, the Permanent Ride Amusement branch of California's Division of Occupational Safety instructed Disney to install additional safety features on the ride.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ocregister.com/articles/changes-disneyland-orange-2291262-suffered-zucker |title=Boy badly hurt in 2000 Roger Rabbit accident dies |date=2009-01-26 |publisher=OC Register |author=Salvador Hernandez and Eric Carpenter |accessdate=2009-02-05 }}</ref> In January 2002, Disney settled with the victim's family, based on the cost of the victim's continuing medical care and suffering; Disney was not required to accept blame.<ref name="toonsettle"/> The victim never fully recovered from his injuries and died in January 2009.<ref name="toonsettle">{{cite news |url = http://www.pantagraph.com/news/article_9e3a0050-3141-5e82-acce-6f226fb5c07e.html |title = Boy dies years after Disneyland ride accident |publisher = AP |date = 2009-01-26 |accessdate = 2010-10-21 }}</ref>
===Skyway=== {{Main|Skyway (Disney)}} *On April 17, 1994, a 30-year-old man fell approximately {{convert|20|ft|m|0}} from one of the gondolas into a tree in front of [[Alice in Wonderland (Disneyland attraction)|Alice in Wonderland]]. Paramedics rescued him and took him to an area hospital for treatment for minor injuries. The man filed a $25,000 lawsuit against Disney, claiming he had simply fallen out of the ride. However, just before the trial date in September 1996, the victim admitted he had indeed purposely jumped out of the ride; the suit was subsequently dropped.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.snopes.com/disney/parks/skyway.asp|title=Skyway to Heaven|work=snopes.com|date=2007-08-23|accessdate=2013-03-02}}</ref>
===Space Mountain=== {{Main|Space Mountain (Disneyland)}} *On August 14, 1979, a 31-year-old woman became ill after riding Space Mountain. At the unload area, she was unable to exit the vehicle. Although employees told her to stay seated while the vehicle was removed from the track, other ride operators did not realize that her vehicle was supposed to be removed and accidentally sent her through the ride a second time. She arrived at the unloading zone semi-conscious. The victim was subsequently taken to Palm Harbor Hospital where she remained in a coma and died one week later. The coroner's report attributed the death to natural causes: a heart tumor had dislodged and entered her brain. A subsequent lawsuit against the park was dismissed.<ref>[[#Koenig94|Koenig 1994]]: 175-176</ref> * In 1983, an 18-year-old man from Quartz Hill, California, fell off Space Mountain and was paralyzed from the waist down. A jury verdict found that Disneyland was blameless in the accident that left the teenager partially paralyzed. During the trial the jury was taken to the park to ride Space Mountain, and several of the cars were brought into the courtroom to demonstrate how they work.<ref>{{cite news |publisher=Los Angeles Times |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1985-03-08/local/me-32412_1_space-mountain-ride |title=Disneyland Ride Victim Loses Lawsuit: Jury Rules Against Man Injured in Space Mountain Accident |author=Steve Tripoli |date=8 March 1985 |accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref>
*On August 2, 2000, nine people suffered minor injuries when the ride's safety control systems caused the train to stop abruptly. This was Space Mountain's first mechanical problem since its opening in 1977.<ref>{{cite news |publisher=Los Angeles Times |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2000/aug/02/local/me-62973 |title=Disneyland closes Space Mountain after accident hurts 9 |author=Jeff Gottlieb and Greg Hernandez |date=2000-08-02 |accessdate=2014-03-11}}</ref> *In April 2013, Disney voluntarily closed Space Mountain, the Matterhorn Bobsleds, and Soarin' Over California due to OSHA-related issues so employee safety protocols could be reviewed. Downtime for each attraction differed, with Space Mountain being closed the longest at one month. The safety review stemmed from seven OSHA fines that were initiated from a contractor injury in November 2012, where the worker fell down the outside of the Space Mountain building and broke several bones. OSHA fined Disney $235,000, and also fined the contracting company $61,000 for safety violations.<ref>{{cite news |publisher=Los Angeles Times |url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-disneylands-space-mountain-temporarily-closed-after-park-cited-20130414,0,7046554.story |title=Disneyland's Space Mountain temporarily closed amid safety review |author=Carlos Lozano |date=2013-04-14 |accessdate=2013-05-22}}</ref>
===Storybook Land Canal Boats=== {{Main|Storybook Land Canal Boats}} * On March 16, 2005, a 4-year-old boy broke a finger and severed the tip of his thumb when the child's fingers were crushed between the boat and the dock while passengers were unloading. The ride was closed for nearly two days while state authorities investigated the accident. Authorities directed Disneyland to lower and repair rubber bumpers along the dock's edge, and to make sure ride operators inform passengers to keep their hands in the boat while it docks.<ref name="Accident">{{cite news | first = | last = | author = | coauthors = | title =Boy breaks finger, severs thumb on Disney ride | url=http://www.wtvm.com/Global/story.asp?S=3097045 | format = | work = | publisher =The Associated Press | pages = | page = | date =July 30, 2005 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20051202121837/http://www.wtvm.com/Global/story.asp?S=3097045 |archivedate = 2 December 2005}}</ref>
===Tom Sawyer's Island=== * On January 21, 2001, a 6-year-old girl lost two-thirds of her left index finger while playing with a toy rifle that was mounted on a turret on the Island's Fort Wilderness. Disney did not report this incident to OSHA, as serious injury accidents need to be reported only if the incident occurred on a ride. The girl was rushed to a hospital, but doctors never reattached her finger. OSHA stated that the incident did not fall under their review, as accidents and injuries that occur on playground equipment do not qualify for OSHA reporting.<ref>{{cite news | title=Girl, 6, Loses Most of Finger at Disneyland | url=http://articles.latimes.com/2001/jan/24/news/mn-16379 | author= Jessica Garrison | publisher = Los Angeles Times | date = 2001-01-24 | accessdate = 2013-04-19 }}</ref>
===Toontown=== * On May 28, 2013, two small explosions in trash cans caused the Toontown area of the park to be evacuated. Officials believe the explosion was caused by [[dry ice bomb|a plastic bottle filled with dry ice (or dry ice bomb)]] taken from a nearby ice cream stand. The bomb squad was called to investigate. No injuries were reported.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-201_162-57586557/no-injuries-in-apparent-dry-ice-disneyland-blast/ |title=No injuries in apparent dry-ice Disneyland blast |date=2013-05-28 |accessdate=2013-05-28 |publisher=CBS News |author=AP}}</ref> A 22-year-old concession stand worker from Long Beach, California was accused of creating and detonating the two dry ice bombs. He pleaded guilty to one misdemeanor count of possession of a destructive device and was sentenced to 36 days in jail, three years of informal probation and 100 hours of community service, and was banned forever from all Disney parks.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/11/04/christian-barnes-sentence_n_4215348.html |title=Christian Barnes, Ex-Disneyland Worker, Sentenced For Dry-ice Bombs |date=2013-11-04 |accessdate=2014-02-13 |author=AP |publisher=Huffington Post}}</ref>
===Costumed characters=== * In 1976, an unidentified woman sued Disney Parks Corporation because she claimed that one of the Three Little Pigs at the "[[It's a Small World]]" attraction grabbed and [[fondling|fondled]] her. She claimed to have gained {{convert|50|lbs|kg}} as a result of the incident and sued Disney for $150,000 in damages for assault and battery, false imprisonment and humiliation. The plaintiff dropped charges after Disney's lawyers presented her with a photo of the costume, which had only inoperable stub arms, a common feature among the shorter characters that was eliminated in later years.<ref name="Koenig206">[[#Koenig94|Koenig 1994]]: 206-207</ref> * An employee who was playing Winnie the Pooh in 1978 was alleged that he slapped a child and caused bruising, recurring headaches and possible brain damage. The worker testified that the girl was tugging at his costume from behind. When he turned around, he accidentally struck the girl in her ear. At one point, the employee entered the courtroom after recess in the Pooh costume and responded to questions while on the witness stand as Pooh would, including [[Two-step (dance move)|dancing]] a [[jig]]. Appearing as Pooh showed the jury that the costume's arms were too low to the ground to slap a girl of the victim's height. The jury acquitted the worker after deliberating for 21 minutes.<ref name="Koenig206"/> * In August 2012, a family claimed an employee playing as [[White Rabbit]] was being racist towards their 6-year-old son by refusing to hug him. Other reported activities involved refusal to hold hands, and refusal to allow the child to sit on the character's lap. The family claimed that the character interacted with white and Asian children. While Disney did offer an apology letter and park passes to the family, the family refused the offer and filed a lawsuit as Disney would not confirm if the employee was still employed. The lawsuit was settled on December 30, 2013.<ref>{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RneP2id5c6M|title=Local family files lawsuit against Disneyland, claims racism|date=4 February 2013|format=YouTube}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2274948/Black-family-accuses-Disneylands-White-Rabbit-racism-refused-touch-kids.html|title=Black family accuses Disneyland's White Rabbit of racism after it 'refused to touch their kids'|date=7 February 2013|work=Mail Online}}</ref><ref>{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=svHVpV6B1zA|title=Family sues Disneyland over racist 'Rabbit' (he wouldn't hold childs hand cause he was black!)|date=7 February 2013|format=YouTube}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ocweekly.com/news/disneyland-settles-white-rabbit-is-racist-lawsuit-in-july-tweets-out-photo-of-mickey-w-black-family-today-coincidence-6465937|title=Disneyland Settles White-Rabbit-is-Racist Lawsuit in July, Tweets Out Photo of Mickey w/Black Family Today--Coincidence?|author=Gustavo Arellano|date=30 December 2013|work=OC Weekly}}</ref>
===Guest altercations=== * On March 7, 1981, an 18-year-old boy was fatally stabbed with a knife during a fight with a 28-year-old man, after the victim supposedly pinched the man's girlfriend in [[Tomorrowland]]. His family sued the park for US$60 million. The jury found the park negligent for not summoning outside medical help and awarded the family US$600,000.<ref>{{cite news |url = https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9A0DE4DE153AF937A15754C0A960948260&n=Top%2fReference%2fTimes%20Topics%2fOrganizations%2fD%2fDisneyland |title = AROUND THE NATION; Disneyland Must Pay $600,000 in Park Murder |publisher = New York Times |date = 1986-07-24 |accessdate = 2006-12-06 }}</ref> *On September 14, 1985, a 7-year-old girl from [[Torrance, California]], was crushed to death beneath the wheels of a bus while on a trip to Disneyland with her uncle. The girl was walking across the parking lot with her uncle, looking for his car, when she fell under a moving charter bus that crushed her. Paramedics pronounced her dead at the scene.<ref>{{cite news |url = https://www.nytimes.com/1985/09/17/us/girl-7-is-crushed-to-death-by-bus-on-trip-to-disneyland.html |title = Girl, 7, Is Crushed to Death By Bus on Trip to Disneyland |publisher = New York Times |date = 1985-09-17 |accessdate = 2016-04-23 }}</ref> *On March 7, 1987, a 15-year-old boy was fatally shot in the Disneyland parking lot.<ref>{{cite news |title=Teen-Ager Killed in Brawl at Disney Lot |first=Maria L. |last=La Ganga |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=8 March 1987 |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1987-03-08/local/me-13418_1_anaheim-police |accessdate=27 October 2010}}</ref> The incident began as an early morning confrontation between rival gang members before escalating into a brawl. Eighteen-year-old Keleti Naea was convicted of second-degree murder, but the conviction was subsequently overturned by a state appellate court.<ref>{{cite news |title=Conviction Overturned in Disneyland Murder |first= |last= |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=3 May 1989 |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1989-05-03/local/me-2604_1_gang-member-disneyland-parking-lot-salesi-tai |accessdate=27 October 2010}}</ref>
===Power outages=== *On December 27, 2017, a major power outage struck the Disneyland Park, that temporarily closed down rides mostly located in Toontown and Fantasyland. Rides that lost power had to be evacuated, however, no assistance from the local fire department were necessary, and no injuries were reported. All attractions were fully operational again later in the day. According to a Disneyland spokesperson, the outage was caused by a transformer failure.<ref>{{cite news |title=Disneyland powers up after outage leaves thousands stranded |newspaper=[[USA Today]] |date=28 December 2017 |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2017/12/28/disneyland-powers-up-after-outage-leaves-thousands-stranded/986705001/ |accessdate=28 December 2017}}</ref>
==Disneyland Hotel== * On September 3, 1994, a 75-year-old man jumped to his death from a 9th floor balcony of the Disneyland Hotel. This was the first suicide known to be committed at the Disneyland Resort.<ref>{{cite news|title=MAN JUMPS TO DEATH FROM BALCONY AT DISNEYLAND HOTEL|url=http://www.apnewsarchive.com/1994/Man-Jumps-to-Death-From-Balcony-at-Disneyland-Hotel/id-c539be36fb33d35242b9d7b6ace1696b|accessdate=6 April 2014|newspaper=Associated Press|date=3 September 1994}}</ref><ref name=OCReg05022008 /> * On July 6, 1996, a 23-year-old man either jumped or fell to his death from the 14th floor of the Disneyland Hotel. He was not a guest of the hotel, and had climbed over several balconies.<ref name=OCReg05022008 /><ref>{{cite news|title=Parolee Dies in Fall at Disneyland Hotel|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1996-07-08/local/me-22171_1_disneyland-hotel|accessdate=6 April 2014|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=8 July 1996}}</ref> * In 1998, a 23-year-old Walt Disney Co. employee jumped from the 14th floor but survived the fall.<ref name=OCReg05022008 /> * On May 2, 2008, a 48-year-old man jumped from a 14th story balcony of the South Tower of the Disneyland Hotel, known as the Wonder Tower, to his death in a parking lot.<ref name="OCReg05022008">{{cite news|title=Authorities ID man who jumped from Disney hotel|url=http://www.ocregister.com/news/jumped-77784-year-old.html|accessdate=6 April 2014|newspaper=Orange County Register|date=5 May 2008|author=DENISSE SALAZAR}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Man jumps to death from Disneyland hotel|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2008/05/02/us-disney-suicide-idUSN0230663820080502|accessdate=6 April 2014|newspaper=Reuters|date=2 May 2008}}</ref>
==Mickey & Friends Parking Structure== * On October 17, 2010, a 61-year-old man from Hickman, California jumped to his death from the top floor of the Mickey & Friends Parking Structure. He left behind a note citing "personal issues" for his suicide.<ref>{{cite news|title=Man Commits Suicide By Jumping Off Mickey & Friends Parking Structure at Disneyland|url=http://blogs.ocweekly.com/navelgazing/2010/10/man_commits_suicide_by_jumping.php|accessdate=6 April 2014|newspaper=OC Weekly|date=21 October 2010|author=Vickie Chang}}</ref> * On April 2, 2012, a 23-year-old man was found near the northwest corner of the Mickey & Friends parking structure, and was pronounced dead at the scene. At the time, it was investigated as a suicide, but there were no witnesses that saw him jump.<ref>{{cite news|title=Man ID'd in deadly Disneyland fall|url=http://www.ocregister.com/news/parking-347423-structure-police.html|accessdate=6 April 2014|newspaper=Orange County Register|date=3 April 2012|author=DENISSE SALAZAR}}</ref> * On November 26, 2016, a 40-year-old man jumped to his death from the Mickey & Friends Parking Structure just after 2:00 a.m. He was rushed to UC Irvine Medical Center and pronounced dead at 3:08 a.m.<ref>{{cite news|title=Officials ID man who died after jumping off parking structure at Disneyland|url=http://www.ocregister.com/articles/structure-736637-death-parking.html|accessdate=3 December 2016|newspaper=Orange County Register|date=26 November 2016|author=CITY NEWS SERVICE}}</ref> * On February 13, 2017, a fire broke out on the second floor of the Mickey & Friends Parking Structure. Seven people were treated for smoke inhalation, while four cars were destroyed with an additional four receiving major damage.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hamilton|first1=Matt|title=Fire inside Disneyland parking structure burns 8 cars, injures 7 people and prompts evacuations|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-fire-disneyland-20170213-story.html|accessdate=14 February 2017|work=latimes.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Multiple Cars Catch Fire in Mickey and Friends Parking Structure at Disneyland; Lot Evacuated|url=http://ktla.com/2017/02/13/multiple-cars-catch-fire-in-parking-structure-at-disneyland/|accessdate=14 February 2017|work=KTLA|date=14 February 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=7 people treated, 8 cars burn in Disneyland parking fire|url=http://www.sfgate.com/news/us/article/Cars-catch-fire-in-Disneyland-parking-structure-10930026.php#photo-12367433|accessdate=14 February 2017|work=SFGate|agency=Associated Press}}</ref> * On August 13, 2018, smoke filled the Mickey and Friends parking structure, forcing visitors to wait outside as firefighters doused the flames. The fire was out in about 30 minutes. Only one car was damaged.<ref>{{cite news|title=Car Fire Fills Disneyland Parking Structure With Smoke - NBC Southern California|url=https://www.nbclosangeles.com/news/local/Disneyland-Anaheim-Parking-Structure-Fire-490711651.html|publisher=|date=2018-08-13|accessdate=2018-08-13}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Amusement park accidents]] *[[List of incidents at Disney parks]]

This is a list of notable people from [[Cheb]] or Eger. {{Expand list|date=January 2017}}
{{Compact ToC|left|Contents}}
==A== *[[Bernhard Adler]] (1753–1810), German-Bohemian doctor and founder of the spa town [[Franzensbad]] in Egerland *[[Hans Hermann Adler]] (1891–1956), German journalist and professor at the [[University of Heidelberg]] *[[Pavel Anděl]] (born 1966), Czech actor, musician, writer, editor and television presenter
==B== *{{ill|Zdenka Becker|de}} (born 1951), Czechoslovak-Austrian writer *{{ill|Frank Boldt|cz}} (1942–2006), German historian, Slavic scholar and translator *{{ill|Jaromír Bosák|cz}} (born 1965), Czech sports commentator and journalist *{{ill|Johann Georg Franz Braun|de}} (before 1638–1670), cantor at St. Nicholas, composer, author of ''Ave Maria zart'' *[[Bretislav III]] (–1197), Czech prince and bishop of Prague's Přemyslid dynasty *{{ill|Balthasar Brusch|de}} (1512–1589), German bookbinder and bookseller, author of the city history and family chronicles *{{ill|Kaspar Brusch|de}} (1518–1559), German humanist, poet and, historian, went to school in Eger *{{ill|Andreas Buberl|de}} (1832–1907), German military doctor, spa doctor, honorary citizen of Eger and Franzensbad
==C== *{{ill|Vojtěch Cach|cz}} (1914–1980), Czech writer and dramatist *{{ill|Mikoláš Chadima|cz}} (born 1952), Czech musician *[[Pablo Clain]] (also known as Pavel Klein and Paul Klein; 1652–1717), German-Czech Jesuit *[[Ilona Csáková]] (born 1970), Czech singer
==D== *[[Albin Dötsch]] (1872–1922), Austrian politician ([[Social Democratic Party of Austria|SDAP]]) *[[Libor Dvořák (journalist)|Libor Dvořák]] (born 1948), Czech journalist and Russian translator
==E== *[[Johannes Sylvius Egranus]] (Johannes Wildauer; around 1480–1553), German theologian, humanist and reformer, friend of [[Martin Luther]] *{{ill|Johann Franz Loew von Erlsfeld|de}} (1648–1725), German-Bohemian doctor and lawyer, Rector of [[Charles University]], went to Eger to school
==F== *[[Martin Fenin]] (born 1987), Czech footballer *[[Adolf Fischer (historian)|Adolf Fischer]] (born 1925), German family and local historian, went to school in Eger
==G== *[[Peter Glotz]] (1939–2005), German [[Social Democratic Party of Germany|SPD]] politician, journalist and media scholar, and member of the German [[Bundestag]] *{{ill|Heinrich Gradl|de}} (1842–1895), German historian and archivist of Eger *{{ill|Marcel Grün|de}} (born 1946), Czech astronomer and writer in the field of astronomy and astronautics *{{ill|Joseph Sebastian Grüner|de}} (1780–1864), superintendent and local historian of Eger *{{ill|Anton Gschier|cz}} (1814–1874), Austro-Hungarian politician
==H== *[[Johann Habermann]] (1516–1590), German Lutheran theologian and devotional writer *{{ill|Josef Hecht|de}} (1792–1861), Franzensbad spa entrepreneur and politician *{{ill|Michael Heuffner|de}} (1483–1511), German sculptor and painter *{{ill|Karl Huss|de}} (1761–1836), executioner, healer and collector
==I==
==J== *[[Ladislav Jakl]] (born 1959), Secretary of the President of the [[Czech Republic]] *{{ill|Wilhelm Jobst|de}} (1912–1947), German physician and [[Nazi]] chief conductor
==K== *[[Daniela Kolářová]] (born 1946), Czech actress *[[Andrej Krob]] (born 1938), Czech theater director and screenwriter
==L== *{{ill|Helmut Lederer|de}} (1919–1999), German sculptor and photographer *{{ill|Abraham Leuthner|de}} (ca. 1639–1701), mason and builder, built the Dominican church and monastery in Cheb
==M== *[[Johann Georg Macasius]] (1617–1653), German physician *{{ill|Adolf Mayerl|de}} (1884–1954), German sculptor and ceramic artist *{{ill|Nikolaus Medler|de}} (1502–1551), German theologian, reformer, and mathematician *{{ill|Mira Mladejovska|cz}} (1895–1969), Czech museum and archive manager *[[Michael Müller (historian)|Michael Müller]] (1849–1914), German physician and local historian
==N== *[[Balthasar Neumann]] (1687–1753), German baroque architect *[[Pavel Nedvěd]] (born 1972), European Footballer of the Year for 2004 *{{ill|Johann Brusch von Neiberg|de}} (1666–1742), German Roman Catholic lawyer and syndic of Eger
==O==
==P==
==Q==
==R== *[[Erich Riedl]] (born 1933), German [[Christian Social Union in Bavaria|CSU]] politician, member of the German Bundestag
==S== *[[Adolf Scherbaum]] (1909–2000), German trumpeter *{{ill|Johann Adam Schertzer|de}} (1628–1683), German Protestant theologian *{{ill|Kaspar Schlick|de}} (ca. 1396–1449), Chancellor of three kings and Chancellor under [[Emperor Sigismund]], a politically important personality of the first half of the 15th century *{{ill|Walther Schuster|de}} (1930–1992), German organist and composer *{{ill|Otmar Seidl|de}} (born 1944), German internist, psychoanalyst and sociologist *[[Rudolf Serkin]] (1903–1991), American pianist of Russian-Jewish origin *{{ill|Kurt Sieber|de}} (born 1936), German politician ([[Free Democratic Party (Germany)|FDP]]) *{{ill|Karl Siegl|de}} (1851–1943), historian, German city archivist and museum director *[[Norbert Singer]] (born 1939), German automotive engineer responsible for many of [[Porsche]]'s victories at the [[24 Hours of Le Mans]] races *{{ill|Rüdiger von Sparneck|de}} (~1300–1364/1368), Viscount of Eger *{{ill|Lorenz Johann Adam Köstler von Stromberg|de}} (1807–1888), Fountain doctor and honorary citizen of Franzensbad and Eger *{{ill|Heribert Sturm|de}} (1904–1981), German city archivist and museum director
==T== *[[Adolf Tachezy]] (1814–1892), Czech businessman, pharmacist and politician, mayor *[[Stanislav Tůma (photographer)|Stanislav Tůma]] (1950–2005), Czech photographer

revision.text:
History of [[Belarus]]ian states can be traced far to [[Principality of Polotsk]]. From 13th century lands of modern Belarus were a major part of the [[Grand Duchy of Lithuania]] which later became part of the [[Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth]]. In 19th century Belarus together with [[Lithuania]] formed the [[Northwestern Krai]] of [[Russian Empire]]. At the beginning of the 20th century there was a short-lived [[Belarusian National Republic]], and in 1922 Belarus became part of the [[USSR]] as [[Belarusian SSR]] except [[West Belarus]], which was under [[Second Polish Republic|Polish]] rule, which was briefly interrupted due to Soviet occupation during [[Polish-Soviet War]]. In 1991, Belarus regained its independence. ==Pre-Rurikid rulers== ===Non-dynastic=== * Vespasius *[[Ragvalod of Polotsk|Ragvalod I]] (? - 980) ==Rurikid Belarus== In 978, with the marriage of [[Rogneda of Polotsk|Rogneda]], daughter of Ragvalod, with [[Vladimir I of Kiev]], the [[Principality of Polotsk]] became property of the [[Rurik Dynasty]]. It was ruled by Rurikid members until the second half of the 14th century, when it was taken by the [[Grand Duchy of Lithuania]]. Between 978 and 1101, the Principality of Polotsk's domain was uncontested in the majority of the Belarusian territory. Polotsk possibly reached the peak of its influence with the access of [[Vseslav the Seer]] to the [[Kievan Rus'|Kievan throne]], but at the death of the latter Polotsk was split in three smaller principalities: a smaller Polotsk, the [[Principality of Minsk]] and the [[Principality of Vitebsk]]. ===[[Rurik Dynasty]]=== The [[Rurik Dynasty|Rurikids]] were descendants of [[Rurik]] (''Hrørekr''), a [[Varangians|Varangian]] pagan [[konung]] or chieftain, who supposedly was of haplogroup [[Haplogroup N (Y-DNA)|N1c1]], which is common among [[Finno-Ugric peoples]] and not so rare in Baltic region. [http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.com/~mozhayski/teksty/ydna.html DNA Testing of the Rurikid and Gediminid Princes] {| width=95% class="wikitable" ! width=20% | Portrait ! width=8% | Name ! width=15% | Born ! width=7% | Reign ! width=16% | Marriage (s) ! width=16% | Death ! width=13% | Notes |- |align="center"|'''[[Vladimir the Great|Vladimir I the Great]]'''

aged c.12-13 | An izgoi (orphan protected by the church), inherited the Principality, but died still as a minor. |- |align="center"|''[[Izgoi]]'' '''[[Bryachislav of Polotsk|Bryachislav I]]'''
Брѧчиславъ сн҃ъ Изѧславль |align="center"| [[File:Bračysłaŭ. Брачыслаў (XV).jpg|100px]] |align="center"|c.997

aged 46–47 |An izgoi until his majority (c.1011), inherited the Principality from his minor brother. Challenged the authority of his uncle, [[Yaroslav the Wise]]. |- |align="center"|''[[Izgoi]]'' '''[[Vseslav of Polotsk|Vseslav II the Seer]]'''
''Vseslav Basil Bryacheslavich''
''(Всеслав Брячиславич)'' |align="center"| [[File:Я. Драздовіч Пярсцёнак князя Усяслава Чарадзея.jpg|100px]] |align="center"| c.1039

1071-1102 |align="center"| ''Unknown''
six sons |align="center"| 24 April 1101
[[Polotsk]]
aged 61–62 | An izgoi until his majority (c.1055), followed the politic of his father, and reached, in 1068, the status of Prince of the [[Kievan Rus']], being deposed in the following year. Was also deposed from Polotsk, which was ruled by the sons of [[Iziaslav I of Kiev]] until 1071. After his death, Polotsk was divided between his sons. |- |align="center"|'''[[Mstislav Iziaslavich|Mstislav I]]'''
''Mstislav Iziaslavich''
''(Мстислав Изяславич)'' |align="center"| |align="center"| After 1043

less than 25-26 | Dethroned Vseslav the Seer, but died in the same year. |- |align="center"|'''[[Sviatopolk II of Kiev|Sviatopolk I]]'''
''Sviatopolk Michael Iziaslavich''
''(Всеволод Ярославич)''

Second son of [[Iziaslav I of Kiev]] and [[Gertrude of Poland]] |align="center"| 1069-1071 |align="center"| ''Unknown name''
''(daughter of [[Spytihněv II, Duke of Bohemia|Spytihněv II of Bohemia]])''According to A. Nazarenko. It was thought not long ago that the first wife of Sviatopolk was Barbara Komnene, a supposed daughter of [[Alexios I Komnenos]]. However, the lack of tradition of such a name in the [[Byzantine Empire]] led to doubt. Today she may be considered fictional.
c.1085

aged 62 | His descendants lost their rights to the Kievan throne. page.title: List of traditional territories of the indigenous peoples of North America

revision.text: This '''list of traditional territories of the original peoples of North America''' gives an overview of the names of the indigenous "countries" of North America. In this sense, "country" refers to the name of the ''land''...the ''ground''...the ''territory'' of a nation, rather than the name of the nation ("tribe") itself. This article is only about the name for the ''land'' of a nation. For example, the traditional territory (country/land) of the Ho-Chunk (Winnebago) Nation is called ''Waaziija'', meaning "the Grand Pinery". In English, the land of an indigenous nation was historically, and sometimes still is, referred to as a "country", such as "(the) Winnebago country". Some Latinate forms exist in English such as "Iroquoia", "Huronia", and "Apacheria". The distinction between nation and land is like the French people versus the land of ''France'', the Māori people versus ''Aotearoa'', or the Saami people versus ''[[Sápmi]]'' (Saamiland). ==List of traditional territories== {| class="sortable wikitable" border="0" cellpadding="0" style="background:white; text-align:left; font-size'':95%; border-collapse'':collapse; border'':0 solid #aaa;" |- !width=35%|Autonym(s) for the traditional territoryWhen the name of a traditional territory has several possible etymologies, only one or a few English translations are given here (for example ''Ojibwewaki'' = "Land of the Record Keepers" is only one of several possibilities). For more, see the Wikipedia article for each nation and the various folk etymologies and proposed etymologies for their national name. ! class="unsortable" style="width:20%;" |Conventional or historic English monikers for the traditional territory, with various attested spellingsThough the column of conventional and historic English monikers is not meant to be a comprehensive list, and though some of the references are ephemeral, this column does give a snapshot of how the traditional territories have been spoken of in everyday English. ! style="width:14%;" |The nation affiliated with that territory ! class="unsortable" |Further information ! style="width:2%" |Wikipedia article?This column contains links to existing articles about a single nation's traditional territory. Ideally such Wikipedia articles would include a composite map which showed how each indigenous national territory is portrayed in all of these: *key maps from scholars, such as the national boundaries from the ''Handbook of North American Indians'', Alfred Kroeber's culture area maps, and Sturtevant's 1967 "Early Indian Tribes, Culture Areas, & Linguistic Stocks" map. *key maps from general sources, such as the tribal boundaries from National Geographic's ''Indians of North America'' map from 1972. *a map of all treaty lands which that nation is a party, as documented in the Royce land cession maps and the Canadian numbered treaties. *the map(s) submitted by each U.S. Indian Nation during the Indian Claims Commission. *the final ICC "judicially established" map. *the NAGPRA "area of interest" map from each U.S. Indian Nation. *a map showing the location of all former reservation lands. *a map of current reservation and trust lands. *the location of national sites and diasporic populations situated outside of those lands—for example, outlying historic villages (such as the [[Bulltown, West Virginia|Bulltown]] Lenape village in what's now West Virginia, which was never a part of Lenape treaty lands) and modern "satellite" communities (for example, the "at-large" Community Groups of the Cherokee Nation). *a map of the State Designated Tribal Statistical Area (SDTSA) for state-recognized Indian Nations. *and most importantly, "tribally-interpreted", "indigenous-approved" maps, such as the traditional territory maps from the ongoing British Columbia Treaty Process, and depictions of legendary boundaries from oral history. |- style="background:Darkgrey;" |align=center|A AAA |A AAA |A AAA |A AAA | |- |valign=top|? French: ''l'Anishinabe Aki''. "The [[Nishnawbe Aski Nation|Nishnawbe Aski]] territory" refers to the land of the amalgamated national identity which was formed in 1983 by the OjiCree-, Ojibway-, Cree-, and Algonquin-speaking bands which were party to the two treaties which cover Northern Ontario.{{cite web |url=http://www.nan.on.ca/article/about-us-3.asp |title=Nishnawbe Aski Nation - About Us |publisher=Nan.on.ca |date= |accessdate=2015-05-16}} See also the entries for ''Ojibwewaki'' (Ojibwa country), ''Bodéwadmiakiwen'' (Potawatomi country), and Omàmiwininiwak (Algonquin) traditional territory. !{{Na}} |- |valign=top|? Francisco Lypez de Gуmara |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2015-05-16}} !{{Na}} |- | valign="top" |'''Chikashsha Yakni''', '''Chikasha yakni'''{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EsfXxhnvy0IC&lpg=PA366&ots=h5VentXKfl&dq=%22chikasha%20yakni%22&pg=PA366#v=onepage&q=%22chikasha%20yakni%22&f=false |title=Chikasha Okla i Kvnstitushvn Micha i Nan Vlhpisa |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2015-05-16}} ("Land of Chicksa") |valign=top|AChickasaw Country,{{cite web |url=http://chickasawcountry.com/explore |title=Things To Do In Oklahoma : Visit the Chickasaw Nation |publisher=Chickasawcountry.com |date= |accessdate=2015-05-16}} the Chickasaw country{{cite web |url=https://www.loc.gov/item/2007630424 |title=Map of the Chickasaw country : and contiguous portions of the Indian Territory / | Library of Congress |publisher=Loc.gov |date= |accessdate=2015-05-16}} |valign=top|A[[Chickasaw|The Chikashsha (Chickasaw) Nation]] {{extent}}In Chickasaw legend, "Chicksa" is the name of the second man to come out of the earth.{{cite web |url=https://chickasaw.net/Our-Nation/History/Prehistoric.aspx |title=The Official Site of the Chickasaw Nation | Prehistoric |publisher=Chickasaw.net |date= |accessdate=2015-05-16}} !{{Na}} |- | valign="top" |'''Denendeh''' ("Land of the People") | valign="top" |Athe Dene country{{cite web |author= |url=http://sarahontheroad.com/2012/03/dene-hand-games/ |title=Dene Hand Games… |publisher=Sarahontheroad.com |date=2012-03-18 |accessdate=2015-05-16}} | valign="top" |AThe ''Dene'' name has two primary meanings: * 1) an identity which encompasses six ethno-linguistic communities: the [[Dehcho First Nations|Dehcho (South Slavey) Nation]], [[Chipewyan people|Dënesųłiné (Chipewyan) Nation]], [[Gwich'in|Dinjii Zhuu (Gwich'in) Nation]], [[Sahtu|Sahtúot’ine (North Slavey) Nation]], [[Yellowknives|T'atsaot'ine (Yellowknives) Nation]], and [[Tli Cho|Tłı̨chǫ (Dogrib) Nation]]. These six historic nations—or at least those portions dwelling in the Northwest Territories—prefer to be called the ''Dene Nation''.[http://www.denenation.com/dene_declaration.html ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130906023851/http://www.denenation.com/dene_declaration.html |date=September 6, 2013 }} * 2) In a wider sense, the name ''[[Dene]]'' encompasses all of the [[Northern Athabaskan]] peoples of Canada and Alaska. {{extent}}The name "Denendeh", though now confined to the NWT, could conceivably be employed as a supra-national name for all the Northern Athabaskan traditional territories as a whole, in a similar way that "Anishinaabewaki" transcends modern political boundaries. See also ''Tłı̨chǫ Ndè'' (Dogrib country). !{{Na}} |- | valign="top" |'''Diné Bikéyah''' ("Land of the People"), '''Naabeehó Bikéyah''',[[Navajo Nation#Name]] '''Dinétah''' ("Among the People") | valign="top"|ANavajoland,{{cite web |url=http://discovernavajo.com/ |title=Home |publisher=Discovernavajo.com |date= |accessdate=2015-05-16}} the Navajo country{{cite web |url=http://www.abebooks.com/book-search/title/military-campaigns-navajo-country-northwestern-new-mexico-1800-1846/page-1/ |title=Military Campaigns Navajo Country Northwestern New Mexico 1800 1846 |publisher=AbeBooks |date= |accessdate=2015-05-16}} | valign="top"|A[[Navajo people|The Diné (Navajo) Nation]] {{extent}}In contrast to ''Diné Bikéyah'', the name ''Dinétah'' can refer specifically to the original homeland, in contrast to the wider territory which resulted from the Navajos' westerly expansion in historic times. The original meaning of the autonym ''Inoca'', ''Inoka'' is presently unknown.{{cite web |author= |url=http://www.press.uillinois.edu/wordpress/?p=1521 |title=Illinois Place Name of the Day – November 3, 2008 |publisher=Press.uillinois.edu |date=2008-11-03 |accessdate=2015-05-17}} !{{Na}} |- |valign=top|'''Inuit Nunaat'''{{cite web |url=https://www.itk.ca/front-page-story/circumpolar-inuit-declaration-arctic-sovereignty |title=Circumpolar Inuit Declaration on Arctic Sovereignty | Inuit Tapiriit Kanatami - Canada's National Inuit Organization |publisher=Itk.ca |date=2008-11-07 |accessdate=2015-05-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150518111337/https://www.itk.ca/front-page-story/circumpolar-inuit-declaration-arctic-sovereignty |archivedate=2015-05-18 |df= }} ("Land of the People") |valign=top|Athe Inuit homeland,{{cite web |url=http://inuitcircumpolar.com/index.php?ID=374&Lang=En |accessdate=July 16, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140706165800/http://www.inuitcircumpolar.com/index.php?ID=374&Lang=En |archivedate=July 6, 2014}} the Inuit country,{{cite web |url=http://www.yale.edu/ynhti/curriculum/units/1991/2/91.02.07.x.html |title=91.02.07: The Inuit Family: A study of its history, beliefs, and images |publisher=Yale.edu |date= |accessdate=2015-05-17}} the Eskimo country{{cite web |url=http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,799209,00.html |title=Cinema: Old Master - TIME |publisher=Content.time.com |date=1948-09-20 |accessdate=2015-05-17}} |valign=top|A[[Inuit|The Inuit (Eskimo) Nation]] ''"We Eskimo are an international community sharing common language, culture, and a common land along the Arctic coast of Siberia, Alaska, Canada and Greenland. Although not a nation-state, as a people, we do constitute a nation."'' —Inuit Circumpolar Council-Alaska{{cite web |url=http://www.iccalaska.org/servlet/content/the_beginning.html |title=ICC's Beginning |publisher=Iccalaska.org |date= |accessdate=2015-05-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150706171659/http://www.iccalaska.org/servlet/content/the_beginning.html |archivedate=2015-07-06 |df= }} {{extent}}''Inuit Nunaat'' is used by the international Inuit Circumpolar Council; for example in the April 2009 "Circumpolar Inuit Declaration on Sovereignty in the Arctic."{{cite web |url=http://www.iccalaska.org/servlet/download?id=15 |title=A Circumpolar Inuit Declaration on Sovereignty in the Arctic |publisher=Iccalaska.org |accessdate=2015-05-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150316114339/http://www.iccalaska.org/servlet/download?id=15 |archivedate=2015-03-16 |df= }} Two months later, in June 2009, the Canadian-sponsored Inuit organization changed the name of the specifically Canadian Inuit regions from ''Inuit Nunaat'' to ''Inuit Nunangat''{{cite web|url=https://www.itk.ca/publication/maps-inuit-nunangat-inuit-regions-canada |title=Maps of Inuit Nunangat (Inuit Regions of Canada) | Inuit Tapiriit Kanatami - Canada's National Inuit Organization |publisher=Itk.ca |date=2009-06-10 |accessdate=2015-05-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150518111355/https://www.itk.ca/publication/maps-inuit-nunangat-inuit-regions-canada |archivedate=2015-05-18 |df= }} ("The People's Land, Water, and Ice").{{cite web |url=http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/3663770-inuit-nunangat-the-people-s-land |title=Inuit Nunangat The People's Land: A Struggle for Survival by John Amagoalik — Reviews, Discussion, Bookclubs, Lists |publisher=Goodreads.com |date=2008-07-06 |accessdate=2015-05-17}} The four Canadian Inuit regions are the [[Inuvialuit Settlement Region]] (Northwest Territories and Northern Yukon), [[Nunavut]] ("Our Land"), [[Nunavik]] ("Great Land", Northern Quebec), and [[Nunatsiavut]] ("Our Beautiful Land", Northern Labrador). There is also [[NunatuKavut]] ("Our Ancient Land"), the traditional territory of the [[NunatuKavut people|NunatuKavummuit]] (Inuit-Metis) of southern Labrador. There are seven [[Alaskan Native Corporation]]s (see ANC link for map) which are predominantly Inuit in composition: [[Arctic Slope Regional Corporation]], [[NANA Regional Corporation]], [[Bering Straits Native Corporation]], [[Calista Corporation]], [[Bristol Bay Native Corporation]], [[Koniag, Incorporated|Koniag, Inc.]], and [[Chugach Alaska Corporation]]. The existing Inuit-affiliated political divisions and regional corporations only partially reflect the traditional cultural and linguistic diversity of the Inuitic peoples.[[Inuit languages#Geographic distribution and variants]] For example, the boundaries of the Danish political entity ''[[Kalaallit Nunaat]]'' are bigger than the traditional territory of the [[Kalaallit]] proper (West Greenland Inuit). There are two other Inuitic peoples in Greenland: the [[Tunumiit]] (East Greenland Inuit), who live in ''[[Tunu]]''[[Tunu]] and the [[Inughuit]] (Polar Eskimos) of [[Avannaa|North Greenland]]. !{{Na}} |- |valign=top|'''Jiwére Máyan''', '''Wadodana Máya'''n{{cite web |url=https://sites.google.com/site/threefoldnow/traditional-territories |title=traditional territories - Threefold Now |publisher=Sites.google.com |date= |accessdate=2015-05-17}} ("Land of the Otoes") |valign=top|AOtoe country,{{cite web |url=http://archiver.rootsweb.ancestry.com/th/read/NORCAL/1999-11/0941477605 |title=RootsWeb: NORCAL-L Re: Fw: Story of the Murphy Party - Part I |publisher=Archiver.rootsweb.ancestry.com |date= |accessdate=2015-05-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208045256/http://archiver.rootsweb.ancestry.com/th/read/NORCAL/1999-11/0941477605 |archivedate=2015-12-08 |df= }} the Otoe country,{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UNYRAAAAYAAJ&lpg=PA141&ots=_x3u-IXFVJ&dq=%22otoe%20country%22&pg=PA141#v=onepage&q=%22otoe%20country%22&f=false |title=Annual Report of the Commissioner of Indian Affairs - United States. So ''Nēhiýānāhk'' serves as a default name for Cree country as a whole, in a similar way that ''Anishinaabewaki'' is based on an Ojibwe spelling, but serves as common name for the entire supra-national Aninishinaabe traditional territory. The traditional territory of the East Crees is called [[Eeyou Istchee (territory)|''Eeyou Istchee'']] and ''Iynu Asci'' ("Land of the People"). ''Eeyou'' or ''Iyyu'' is the spelling in northern East Cree, while ''Iynu'' in southern East Cree. The traditional territory of the Plains Cree in particular is ''Paskwāwiýinīnāhk'' ("In the Land of the Plains Cree"). !{{Na}} |- |valign=top|'''Newe Segobia'''{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eu5cxvjC3pwC&lpg=PA180&ots=TREw41Ap_h&dq=newe%20sogobia%20earth%20mother&pg=PA180#v=onepage&q=newe%20sogobia%20earth%20mother&f=false |title=Water Follies: Groundwater Pumping and the Fate of America's Fresh Waters - Robert Jerome Glennon |publisher=Books.google.com |date=2004-01-14 |accessdate=2015-05-17}} ("The People's Earth Mother") |valign=top|AWestern Shoshone country,{{cite web |url=http://www.nativeweb.org/pages/legal/shoshone/pamphlet.html |title=How To Kill A Nation |publisher=Nativeweb.org |date=1991-09-05 |accessdate=2015-05-17}} the Western Shoshone homeland,{{cite web |author= |url=http://indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com/2002/06/01/western-shoshone-fight-87803 |title=The Western Shoshone fight on - ICTMN.com |publisher=Indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com |date= |accessdate=2015-05-17}} Newe Country,{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ohQOAQAAMAAJ&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=newe+country |title=The State of Native America: Genocide, Colonization, and Resistance - M. O'odham bands are now broken up into 4 federally recognized tribes: the Tohono O'odham Nation, the Gila River Indian Community, the Ak-Chin Indian Community and the Salt River (Pima Maricopa) Indian community."'' (quote from the Tohono O'odham Nation website){{cite web |url=http://www.tonation-nsn.gov/history_culture.aspx |title=Tohono O'odham Nation - History & Culture |publisher=Tonation-nsn.gov |date= |accessdate=2015-05-17}} In contrast to the entire traditional territory, ''O'odham ha-jeweḍga'' refers to the political Tohono O'odham Indian Reservation. ''Tohono'' ("Desert") is the O'odham name for the [[Tohono O'odham|Tohono O'odham (Pagago)]] portion of ''O'odham Jeweḍ''. The Spanish name for this portion is ''Papaguería'', which has also been used in English. The name "Tohono country", "the tohono jewed",{{cite web |url=http://desertmusingsbytbyrd.blogspot.com/2005/09/hang-right-tallest-cactus.html |title=Desert Musings: Hang a right @ the tallest cactus |publisher=Desertmusingsbytbyrd.blogspot.com |date=2005-09-16 |accessdate=2015-05-17}} "Papago country",{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Z_bBEE5mVAsC&lpg=PA76&dq=%22in%20papago%20country%22&pg=PA76#v=onepage&q=%22in%20papago%20country%22&f=false |title=Of Earth and Little Rain: The Papago Indians - Bernard L. The name was perceived by the early English settlers to be the native equivalent for what they called "Virginia". ''Tsenacommacah'' appears to be cognate with Ojibwe ''danakamigad'' "be an activity, be an event, happen".
